That which necessitates faith in this matter from the Qur'an, the Sunnah, and the statements of the scholars is too numerous to be enumerated. Allah the Exalted said: "And he who restrains the soul [nafs] from caprice [hawa], then indeed Paradise is the refuge." And He the Exalted said: "Those are the ones whose hearts Allah has tested for God-consciousness [taqwa]." It is said: He extracted from them the love of appetites.

Indeed, the eleventh affliction is mockery [sukhriyah] and derision [istihza']. And that may be through imitation in action and speech, and it may be through gesture and indication. And this is only forbidden regarding one who is harmed by it. As for one who makes himself an object of mockery, and perhaps even delights in being mocked, then mockery regarding him is from the category of jesting â€” and what is blameworthy and what is praiseworthy in it has preceded. The forbidden is only the belittlement that harms the one being ridiculed, due to what it contains of contempt and disregard. And that is sometimes by laughing at his speech if he falters in it and it is not coherent, or at his actions if they are confused, such as laughing at his handwriting and at his handiwork, or at his appearance and his form if he is short or deficient due to some defect. [The Fourth Chapter of the Foundations of Belief] concerning faith [iman] and submission [islam] and the connection between them, and what may affect them of increase and decrease, and the manner of the predecessors' exception in it. And in it are three issues. [Issue] They differed regarding whether submission [islam] is faith [iman] or other than it. And if it is other, then is it separate from it, existing without it, or linked to it, inseparable from it? So it was said they are one thing, and it was said they are two things not connected, and it was said they are two things but one is linked to the other. Abu Talib al-Makki has presented on this speech of severe confusion and much length. So let us now rush to declare the truth directly, without digressing to relay what has no benefit. We say in this three investigations: an investigation into what the two terms necessitate in language, an investigation into what is intended by them in the usage of the Sacred Law, and an investigation into their ruling in this world [dunya] and the Hereafter. The first investigation is linguistic, the second is interpretive, and the third is jurisprudential and legal. **The First Investigation:** Concerning what language necessitates. The truth in it is that faith [iman] is an expression for affirmation [tasdiq]. Allah, the Exalted, says: {And you are not a believer for us} meaning an affirmer. And submission [islam] is an expression for surrender [taslim] and yielding [istislam] through acquiescence and compliance, and abandoning rebellion, refusal, and obstinacy. Affirmation [tasdiq] has a specific locus, which is the heart [qalb], and the tongue is its interpreter. As for surrender [taslim], it is general to the heart [qalb], the tongue, and the limbs. For every affirmation [tasdiq] by the heart [qalb] is a surrender [taslim] and an abandonment of refusal and denial. Likewise, the acknowledgment by the tongue. Likewise, obedience and compliance by the limbs. So what language necessitates is that submission [islam] is more general and faith [iman] is more specific. Thus, faith [iman] is an expression for the most noble part of submission [islam]. Therefore, every affirmation [tasdiq] is a surrender [taslim], but not every surrender [taslim] is an affirmation [tasdiq]. **The Second Investigation:** Concerning the usage of the Sacred Law. The truth in it is that the Sacred Law has come using them interchangeably and concurrently, and has come with a distinction, and has come with overlap. As for interchangeability, it is in His saying, the Exalted: {So We brought out whoever was in it of the believers. And We found not within it except one house of those who had submitted [muslimin].} And there was, by agreement, only one house. And He, the Exalted, said: {O my people, if you have believed in Allah, then upon Him rely, if you should be submitters [muslimin].} As for distinction, it is His saying, the Exalted: {The Bedouins say, "We have believed." Say, "You have not believed; but say, 'We have submitted [aslamna],'"} and its meaning is: we have surrendered outwardly. So He intended by faith [iman] here affirmation [tasdiq] by the heart [qalb] only, and by submission [islam] outward surrender [istislam] by the tongue and limbs. And in the hadith of Gabriel, peace be upon him, when he asked him about faith [iman], he said: "That you believe in Allah and His angels and His books and His messengers and the Last Day, and in resurrection after death, and in the Reckoning, and in the Decree, its good and its evil." Then he said: "So what is submission [islam]?" So he answered by mentioning the five pillars. Thus, he expressed submission [islam] as the surrender [taslim] of the outward through speech and action. And in the hadith concerning Sa'd, that he (gave a gift to a man and did not give to another. So Sa'd said to him: "O Messenger of Allah, you left so-and-so, you did not give him, and he is a believer [mu'min]." So he said: "Or a submitter [muslim]." He repeated it to him, and the Messenger of Allah repeated it.) As for overlap, it is what was also narrated that he was asked: "Which deeds are best?" He said: "Submission [islam]." He said: "Which submission [islam] is best?" He said: "Faith [iman]." This is evidence for distinction and for overlap. And it is the most suitable of the usages in language, because faith [iman] is an action from among the actions, and it is the best of them. And submission [islam] is surrender [taslim], whether by the heart [qalb], or by the tongue, or by the limbs. And the best of it is that which is by the heart [qalb], which is affirmation [tasdiq] that is called faith [iman]. And the usage of them for distinction, and for overlap, and for interchangeability, all of it is not outside the path of figurative usage in language. As for distinction, it is to make faith [iman] an expression for affirmation [tasdiq] by the heart [qalb] only, which agrees with language. And submission [islam] an expression for outward surrender [taslim], which also agrees with language. For surrender [taslim] with some of the places of surrender [taslim] is applied to it the name of surrender [taslim]. It is not a condition for the realization of the name that the meaning be general to every place the meaning can exist within. For whoever touches another with some part of his body is called a toucher, even if it does not encompass all of his body. So applying the name submission [islam] to outward surrender [taslim] when there is no surrender of the inward conforms to language. And upon this meaning proceeded His saying, the Exalted: {The Bedouins say, "We have believed." Say, "You have not believed; but say, 'We have submitted [aslamna],'"} and His saying in the hadith of Sa'd: "Or a submitter [muslim]" because he preferred one of them over the other, intending by distinction the superiority of the two named things. As for overlap, it also agrees with language in the specificity of faith [iman], which is to make submission [islam] an expression for surrender [taslim] by the heart [qalb], speech, and action all together, and faith [iman] an expression for some of what entered into submission [islam], which is affirmation [tasdiq] by the heart [qalb].
